title: Quiz 2: Specific STIs - Diagnosis & Management
topicName: Unit Six: STIs and HIV AIDS
description: Deep dive into specific STI conditions, including Chancroid, Syphilis, Herpes, PID, and their clinical management.

questions.question: Which microorganism causes Chancroid?
questions.explanation: Chancroid is caused by the gram-negative bacterium Haemophilus Ducreyi.
questions.hint: It is a bacterium, not a virus or spirochete.

questions.question: Differentiate between the types of Genital Ulcers:

pairs.right: Painful, dirty looking, irregular margins, bleeds easily
Painless, indurated, clean base, raised edges
Localised clusters of vesicles that break into ulcers
Painless ulcers with little/no inflammation affecting bones

questions.explanation: Chancroid is painful/dirty; Syphilis chancre is painless/clean; Herpes presents as vesicles/blisters.
questions.hint: Focus on Pain vs. Painless and the appearance (dirty vs. clean).

questions.question: Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID) often presents with lower abdominal pain and ___BLANK___ tenderness. It is a complication of untreated ___BLANK___.
questions.explanation: PID is a complication of cervicitis where bacteria spread to internal organs, causing pain and tenderness.
questions.hint: The first blank relates to a type of tenderness checked during palpation.

questions.question: Which of the following are complications of untreated Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: PID can scar fallopian tubes leading to infertility and ectopic pregnancy. It also causes chronic pain. Ophthalmia neonatorum affects the newborn, not the woman.
questions.hint: Think about the long-term effects on the reproductive organs.

questions.question: In the management of vaginal discharge, if a patient is pregnant, Metronidazole should NOT be prescribed.
questions.explanation: Metronidazole is generally avoided or used with caution in pregnancy (especially first trimester) according to many guidelines referenced in the text.
questions.hint: Consider the safety of the fetus.

questions.question: Order the steps for managing a newborn with Ophthalmia Neonatorum:

items.text: Notice purulent discharge within 21 days of life
Start treatment immediately (Procaine Penicillin + Tetracycline ointment)
If no improvement, change to Erythromycin syrup

questions.explanation: Immediate treatment is crucial to prevent blindness. Review is done at 24 hours to check efficacy.
questions.hint: Diagnosis -> Immediate Treatment -> Review -> Second Line Treatment.

questions.question: Review the treatment protocol below. Which condition is being treated?

richContent.content:
• Norfloxacin 800mg stat
  • Doxycycline 100mg BD x 7 days
  • PLUS: Metronidazole 400mg BD x 10 days

questions.explanation: This combination covers Gonorrhea, Chlamydia, and Anaerobes, which is the standard syndromic treatment for PID.
questions.hint: Note the addition of Metronidazole for 10 days, typical for PID.

questions.question: What is the incubation period for Chancroid in men?
questions.explanation: The incubation period for Chancroid in men is 4 to 7 days.
questions.hint: It is less than a week.

questions.question: Which of the following is an acute complication of Chancroid in males?
questions.explanation: Phimosis is an acute complication caused by oedema. Auto amputation is a chronic complication.

questions.question: Congenital syphilis is acquired through vertical transmission from mother to unborn baby.
questions.explanation: True. Treponema pallidum can cross the placental barrier, causing congenital syphilis.
questions.hint: Does the bacteria cross the placenta?
